discussion.content: According to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/new-malwarefilterpolicy?view=exchange-ps DeleteMessage actions changes depending on mailbox location: "In Exchange Server, the message is deleted. In the cloud-based service, the message is quarantined." Accordingly, Quarantine and Junk Mail Folder should be the correct responses.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You run the commands shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
YYN
1: Admin1 is part of Organization Admin which is not limited by the scope.
2: Admin2 is part of ExecAdmins which is within the write scope of database name starting with Admin*.
3: MBX-DB1 is outside of the write scope.
should be B not D. only Get-Mailbox has litigationhold info.

Get-Mailbox admin | FL LitigationHoldOwner,LitigationHoldDate
the good answer is B&C according to ti the following link
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/set-mailbox?view=exchange-ps

Answer is BC. D is wrong because Get-MailboxStatistics cmdlet does not have switch for litigation hold and in place hold
Ref: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/get-mailboxstatistics?view=exchange-ps

choices.A: From the Exchange admin center, run an In-place eDiscovery and Hold report.
choices.C: From the Exchange admin center. run a per-mailbox Litigation Hold report.
choices.D: From PowerShell, run the Get-MailboxStatistics cmdlet.
choices.B: From PowerShell, run the Get-Mailbox cmdlet.

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization.
You are auditing the Litigation Hold on the mailboxes of the company's research and development department.
You discover that the mailbox of a user named User1 has a Litigation Hold enabled.
You need to discover who placed the Litigation Hold on the mailbox of User1, and when the Litigation Hold was enabled.
Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
A safe attachments policy that uses Dynamic Delivery is applied to all recipients who match your SMTP domains.
You need to prevent attachments form being scanned when internal users send email to one another.
What should you do?

discussion.content: Create a transport rule---by pass spam filtering: specify senders (inside the organization or domain name) and recipients (inside the organization or domain name).
Create a transport rule to set message header, X-MS-Exchange-Organization-SkipSafeAttachmentProcessing with 1

choices.C: From the Exchange admin center, create a transport rule.
choices.D: From the Exchange admin center, modify the malware filter.
choices.B: From the Security & and Compliance admin center, modify the Service assurance settings.
choices.A: From the Security & and Compliance admin center, modify the safe attachments policy.

discussion.content: A higher BCL indicates a bulk message is more likely to generate complaints (and is therefore more likely to be spam). https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/bulk-complaint-level-values?view=o365-worldwide
